fr.sii.ogham.email.builder

Class ImageInliningBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.fluent.AbstractParent<ImageHandlingBuilder>
      • fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.ImageInliningBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<ContentTranslator>, ResourceResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder>, Parent<ImageHandlingBuilder>

    public class ImageInliningBuilder
extends AbstractParent<ImageHandlingBuilder>
implements ResourceResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder>, Builder<ContentTranslator>
    Configures how images declared in the HTML content are automatically transformed to make it work with email. Images can be either:
    • Attached to the email
    • Encoded to a base64 string
    • Not inlined at all
    This builder is used to enable the inlining modes (and to configure them). Several modes can be enabled.

    If attach() is called, it enables image attachment. Image defined in a html must be referenced by a Content-ID (or CID) if the image is attached to the email. For example, if your template contains the following HTML code: 

     
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" data-inline-image="attach" />
    Then the image will be loaded from the classpath and attached to the email. The src attribute will be replaced by the Content-ID.

    If base64() is called, it enables inlining by converting image content into base64 string and using the base64 string as image source. For example, if your template contains the following HTML code: 

     
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" data-inline-image="base64" />
    Then the image will be loaded from the classpath and encoded into a base64 string. This base64 string is used in the src attribute of the image.

    If you don't want to inline a particular image, you can set the "data-inline-image" attribute to "skip": 

     
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" data-inline-image="skip" />
    Then the image won't be inlined at all.

    If no inline mode is explicitly defined on the <img>: 

     
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" />
    The behavior depends on what you have configured:
    • If attach() is enabled (has been called), then image will be loaded from the classpath and attached to the email. The src attribute will be replaced by the Content-ID.
    • If attach() is not enabled (never called) and base64() is enabled (has been called), then the image will be loaded from the classpath and encoded into a base64 string. This base64 string is used in the src attribute of the image.
    • If neither attach() nor base64() are enabled (never called), then images won't be inlined at all
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Method Detail

      • attach

        public AttachImageBuilder attach()
        Configures how attachment of images is handled.

        If this method is called, it enables image attachment. Image defined in a html must be referenced by a Content-ID (or CID) if the image is attached to the email. For example, if your template contains the following HTML code: 

         
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" data-inline-image="attach" />
        Then the image will be loaded from the classpath and attached to the email. The src attribute will be replaced by the Content-ID.

        In the same way, if your template contains the following code: 

         
  <style>
     .some-class {
       background: url('classpath:/foo.png');
       --inline-image: attach;
     }
  </style>
        Or directly on style attribute: 
         
 	<div style=
	"background: url('classpath:/foo.png'); --inline-image: attach;"></div>
        Then the image will be loaded from the classpath and attached to the email. The url will be replaced by the Content-ID.

        If no inline mode is defined, image attachment is used by default: 

         
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" />
        Or: 
         
  <style>
     .some-class {
       background: url('classpath:/foo.png');
     }
  </style>
        Or: 
         
 	<div style="background: url('classpath:/foo.png');"></div>
        The examples above have the same result as the example that explicitly defines the inline mode.
        Returns:
        the builder to configure how images are automatically attached

      • base64

        public Base64InliningBuilder base64()
        Configures how attachment of images is handled.

        If this method is called, it enables inlining by converting image content into base64 string and using the base64 string as image source. For example, if your template contains the following HTML code: 

         
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" data-inline-image="base64" />
        Then the image will be loaded from the classpath and encoded into a base64 string. This base64 string is used in the src attribute of the <img>.

        In the same way, if your template contains the following code: 

         
  <style>
     .some-class {
       background: url('classpath:/foo.png');
       --inline-image: base64;
     }
  </style>
        Or directly on style attribute: 
         
 	<div style="background: url('classpath:/foo.png'); --inline-image: base64;"></div>
        Then the image will be loaded from the classpath and encoded into a base64 string. The url is updated with the base64 string.

        If no inline mode is defined and image attachment is not enable (attach() is not called), this mode is used by default: 

         
    <img src="classpath:/foo.png" />
        In this case, the example above as the same result as the example that explicitly defines the inline mode.
        Returns:
        the builder to configure how images are automatically converted to base64

      • mimetype

        public MimetypeDetectionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder> mimetype()
        Builder that configures mimetype detection. There exists several implementations to provide the mimetype:
        • Using Java MimetypesFileTypeMap
        • Using Java 7 Files.probeContentType(java.nio.file.Path)
        • Using Apache Tika
        • Using JMimeMagic

        Both implementations provided by Java are based on file extensions. This can't be used in most cases as we often handle InputStreams.

        In previous version of Ogham, JMimeMagic was used and was working quite well. Unfortunately, the library is no more maintained.

        You can configure how Tika will detect mimetype: 

         .mimetype()
    .tika()
       ...

        This builder allows to use several providers. It will chain them until one can find a valid mimetype. If none is found, you can explicitly provide the default one: 

         .mimetype()
    .defaultMimetype("text/html")

        If no mimetype detector was previously defined, it creates a new one. Then each time you call mimetype(), the same instance is used.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure mimetype detection

      • mimetype

        public ImageInliningBuilder mimetype(MimetypeDetectionBuilder<?> builder)
        NOTE: this is mostly for advance usage (when creating a custom module). Inherits mimetype configuration from another builder. This is useful for configuring independently different parts of Ogham but keeping a whole coherence. The same instance is shared meaning that all changes done here will also impact the other builder.

        If a previous builder was defined (by calling mimetype() for example), the new builder will override it.

        Parameters:
        builder - the builder to inherit
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • classpath

        public ClassPathResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder> classpath()
        Description copied from interface: ResourceResolutionBuilder
        Configure resource resolution based on classpath.

        You can define the lookup (the prefix that indicates that classpath resolution must be used). For example: 

         .classpath().lookup("classpath:");
 
 // path prefixed by classpath: matches 
 // then classpath resolver is used
 resourceResolver.getResource("classpath:foo/bar.html");
 // path is not prefixed (or using another prefix) doesn't match 
 // then classpath resolver is not used
 resourceResolver.getResource("foo/bar.html");

        You can define a path prefix and suffix for finding resources: 

         .classpath().lookup("classpath:").pathPrefix("foo/").pathSuffix(".html");
 
 resourceResolver.getResource("classpath:bar");
        This will use the classpath resolver and the real path is foo/bar.html.
        Specified by:
        classpath in interface ResourceResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder>
        Returns:
        the builder to configure classpath resolution

      • file

        public FileResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder> file()
        Description copied from interface: ResourceResolutionBuilder
        Configure resource resolution based on filesystem.

        You can define the lookup (the prefix that indicates that filesystem resolution must be used). For example: 

         .file().lookup("file:");
 
 // path prefixed by file: matches 
 // then file resolver is used
 resourceResolver.getResource("file:foo/bar.html");
 // path is not prefixed (or using another prefix) doesn't match 
 // then file resolver is not used
 resourceResolver.getResource("foo/bar.html");

        You can define a path prefix and suffix for finding resources: 

         .file().lookup("file:").pathPrefix("foo/").pathSuffix(".html");
 
 resourceResolver.getResource("file:bar");
        This will use the file resolver and the real path is foo/bar.html.
        Specified by:
        file in interface ResourceResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder>
        Returns:
        the builder to configure file resolution

      • string

        public StringResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder> string()
        Description copied from interface: ResourceResolutionBuilder
        Configure lookup to use for direct string (when you provide directly the content of a file as string).

        You can define the lookup (the prefix that indicates that direct string must be used). For example: 

         .string().lookup("string:", "s:");
 
 // path prefixed by string: matches 
 // then string is used
 resourceResolver.getResource("string:hello world");
 // path is not prefixed (or using another prefix) doesn't match 
 // then string resolver is not used
 resourceResolver.getResource("foo/bar.html");
        Specified by:
        string in interface ResourceResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder>
        Returns:
        the builder to configure string resolution

      • resolver

        public ImageInliningBuilder resolver(ResourceResolver resolver)
        Description copied from interface: ResourceResolutionBuilder
        Register a custom resolver.

        This may be useful to use a custom implementation that is able to load file content from anywhere.

        The implementation may be aware of the lookup prefix (see AbstractPrefixedLookupPathResolver). The implementation may also use pathPrefix and pathSuffixes (see RelativeResolver and RelativisableResourceResolver).

        Specified by:
        resolver in interface ResourceResolutionBuilder<ImageInliningBuilder>
        Parameters:
        resolver - the custom resolver instance
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
